message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes are also known as cytotoxic T cells and can recognize and destroy cells infected with viruses by exocytosis of granule contents, which activates caspases and leads to programmed cell death (apoptosis). Macrophages and neutrophils play a role in innate immune response, while eosinophils are more commonly associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes, also known as cytotoxic T cells, are responsible for destroying infected cells through exocytosis of granule contents and activation of caspases. Macrophages and neutrophils are phagocytic cells that engulf and digest pathogens, while eosinophils are involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes are responsible for cell-mediated immune responses, including destroying target cells infected with viruses by exocytosis of granule contents, inducing the activation of caspases, and inducing apoptosis. Macrophages and neutrophils are involved in phagocytosis, while eosinophils are involved in the defense against parasitic infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes are responsible for cytotoxic T cell-mediated immunity, which involves the recognition and destruction of virus-infected cells. This process involves the exocytosis of granule contents, which activates caspases, leading to apoptosis of the infected cell. Macrophages play a role in phagocytosis and antigen presentation. Neutrophils are involved in the innate immune response and release of cytokines. Eosinophils are involved in allergic and parasitic infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes, or cytotoxic T cells, are responsible for the exocytosis of granule contents that induce apoptosis in infected or cancerous cells. This process is known as programmed cell death or apoptosis. Macrophages and neutrophils participate in immune responses but do not have this specific function, while eosinophils are involved in allergic reactions and fighting parasitic infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes are responsible for the process of destroying target cells infected with viruses by exocytosis of granule contents, which induces the activation of caspases. Macrophages and neutrophils are involved in phagocytosis, while eosinophils are involved in parasitic infections and allergic reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes, also known as cytotoxic T cells, are responsible for inducing apoptosis in target cells infected with viruses. They do this by releasing granules containing perforin, granzymes, and other cytotoxic proteins that induce the activation of caspases, leading to the destruction of the infected cell. Macrophages help phagocytose and digest foreign particles, neutrophils help fight bacterial infections, and eosinophils are involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes, also known as cytotoxic T cells, are responsible for destroying target cells infected with viruses through the exocytosis of granule contents, which induces the activation of caspases. Macrophages and neutrophils are involved in the immune response but do not directly induce apoptosis in target cells. Eosinophils are primarily involved in allergic reactions and defense against parasites.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes are responsible for cytotoxic T cell responses which can destroy infected cells through exocytosis of granule contents and activation of caspases. Macrophages, neutrophils and eosinophils are also involved in host defense mechanisms but do not specifically carry out this process.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD8+ lymphocytes are responsible for cell-mediated immunity and can directly kill infected cells via exocytosis of granule contents, leading to the activation of caspases and apoptosis. Macrophages, neutrophils, and eosinophils are involved in immune response but do not directly induce apoptosis via exocytosis.
